newsitem.title: USA: Teens charged in brutal Central Park killing.
newsitem.headline: Teens charged in brutal Central Park killing.

text.p: Two teenagers from affluent Manhattan neighbourhoods were charged Friday for the murder of a man was found floating in a lake in Central Park with his throat slashed.

Police said a 15-year-old boy and his 15-year-old girlfriend, both from comfortable neighbourhoods adjoining the park, had been drinking beer at the lakeside with the 44-year-old man after midnight when there was a dispute involving the girl.

"At some point, the 15-year-old boy stabbed him multiple times and threw his body in the lake," New York City Police Commissioner Howard Safir told a news conference. He called it "a gruesome, horrible murder."

The victim had large gashes around the throat, abdomen, face and wrist, Safir said. An unspecified amount of money had been taken from his wallet and a knife was recovered that police believed was used in the crime.
Police said the victim lived in Manhattan but declined to identify him until relatives were notified. All three knew each other and were known to frequent the park, police said.

The teens were identified as Christopher Vasquez and Daphne Abdella. The girl is from a wealthy family living on Central Park West, the avenue alongside the park that is home to some of New York's most affluent residents.
Police said Vasquez also lived near the park, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan off Fifth Avenue, another well-off neighbourhood.

Abdella and Vasquez were both charged with second degree murder and depraved indifference for human life, intentional murder and robbery. They were expected to be arraigned Saturday and indicted by a grand jury next week, officials said. If convicted they would face 25 years to life in jail.
The killing was the first in Central Park since the September 1995 murder of Brazilian runner Maria Pinto Moneiro Alves. That murder has not been solved.

Officials said police became aware of the killing after three emergency calls -- one from a private citizen, one from the girl's father reporting the girl was missing and the third from the girl herself.
